responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Improper handling of command-line arguments
    analysis: |
      The `run.js` script passes any command-line arguments from `process.argv` to the `java` command that runs the Selenium server. This could allow an attacker to inject arbitrary command-line options or other commands into the `java` command, leading to command injection.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names:
      - spawn
    filenames:
      - run.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Use of hard-coded credentials
    analysis: |
      The `install.js` script downloads files from hard-coded URLs (`jarURL` and `chromeDriverURL`). An attacker who can perform a man-in-the-middle attack on the HTTP connections could serve malicious binaries to be downloaded and executed.
    cwe: CWE-798
    function_names:
      - downloadFile
    filenames:
      - install.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Missing error handling
    analysis: |
      The `doThings` function in `install.js` does not properly handle errors. If an error occurs in one of the asynchronous operations, it will be swallowed and the script will continue executing, potentially leading to undefined behavior.
    cwe: CWE-755
    function_names:
      - doThings
    filenames:
      - install.js
    classification: slightly promising

  - headline: Improper file permissions
    analysis: |
      The `chmod` function in `install.js` sets the permissions of the `chromedriver` binary to 0777 (read, write, and execute for all users) on non-Windows platforms. This could lead to insecure file permissions and allow unauthorized users to modify or execute the binary.
    cwe: CWE-732
    function_names:
      - chmod
    filenames:
      - install.js
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Improper handling of command-line arguments
leads.analysis: The run.js script passes any command-line arguments from process.argv to the java command that runs the Selenium server. This could allow an attacker to inject arbitrary command-line options or other commands into the java command, leading to command injection.

leads.headline: Use of hard-coded credentials
leads.analysis: The install.js script downloads files from hard-coded URLs (jarURL and chromeDriverURL). An attacker who can perform a man-in-the-middle attack on the HTTP connections could serve malicious binaries to be downloaded and executed.

leads.headline: Missing error handling
leads.analysis: The doThings function in install.js does not properly handle errors. If an error occurs in one of the asynchronous operations, it will be swallowed and the script will continue executing, potentially leading to undefined behavior.

leads.headline: Improper file permissions
leads.analysis: The chmod function in install.js sets the permissions of the chromedriver binary to 0777 (read, write, and execute for all users) on non-Windows platforms. This could lead to insecure file permissions and allow unauthorized users to modify or execute the binary.
